اس "انتظار" کے مذہبی توسیع میں تغیرات ابھرتے ہیں۔ شیعہ التباطابائی (*العزان*) اور القومی جیسے امامیٹ کے نظریے کے اندر*انٹیزر*کو سیاق و سباق سے دوچار کرتے ہیں ، اور انصاف کے قیام کے لئے مومنوں کی چوکسی کی توقع کے طور پر مومنوں کی چوکسی کی ترجمانی کرتے ہیں۔ یہ شیعہ ایسکیٹولوجی کے ساتھ صف بندی کرتا ہے ، جہاں پوشیدہ امام کا انتظار کرنا ایک فعال روحانی ریاست بن جاتا ہے جس کی اخلاقی تیاری کی ضرورت ہوتی ہے۔ اس کے برعکس ، ابن کتھیر اور الراجی جیسے سنی مبصرین نے آیت کی فوری تاریخی گونج پر توجہ مرکوز کی ، اور مہدی سے واضح تعلق کے بغیر ، آزمائشوں کے دوران ایمان کی عمومی کرنسی کے طور پر "انتظار" کا آغاز کیا۔ مسیحی تشریحات سے پرہیز کرتے ہوئے ، العراجی کا * مافاتیہ الغیب * وجودی صبر کے فلسفیانہ جہت پر زور دیتا ہے۔

یہ اختلافات الگ الگ مذہبی فریم ورک کی عکاسی کرتے ہیں: شیعہ ریڈنگ آیت کو الہامی رہنمائی کی قیادت کی ایک وسیع داستان میں ضم کرتی ہے ، جبکہ سنی کی توثیق آفاقی اخلاقی اصولوں کو ترجیح دیتی ہے۔ عملی طور پر ، شیعہ کمیونٹیز *انٹیزر *کے بارے میں ان کی تفہیم میں اماموں کے ساتھ عقیدت پر زور دے سکتی ہیں ، جبکہ سنی تشریحات مخصوص اسکیٹولوجیکل شخصیات کے بغیر اجتماعی استقامت کو متاثر کرتی ہیں۔ تاریخی طور پر ، یہ تغیرات قائدانہ جانشینی اور اے ایچ ایل ال بیت کے کردار کے بارے میں ابتدائی بحث و مباحثے سے پیدا ہوتے ہیں ، جو بعد میں نظریاتی پیشرفتوں میں کرسٹل کرتے ہیں۔ تاہم ، دونوں روایات آیت کے بنیادی پیغام کو برقرار رکھتی ہیں: خدائی انصاف پر اعتماد دنیاوی مشکلات سے بالاتر ہے۔

123.layer1:
This verse from Surah Hud carries profound reminders about Allah's absolute authority and intimate awareness of creation. At its core, it teaches that both the visible world and hidden realities (ghayb) of the heavens and earth belong exclusively to Allah. The term ghayb refers not just to physical secrets like celestial orbits or quantum particles, but to all knowledge beyond human perception – future events, spiritual truths, and the ultimate outcomes of worldly affairs. By affirming that "to Him will be returned the matter (al-amr)," the Quran emphasizes divine sovereignty over every aspect of existence, from cosmic phenomena to personal struggles.

Revealed during Prophet Muhammad's challenging Meccan period, this verse comforted early Muslims facing persecution. Its instruction to "worship Him and rely upon Him" (fa'budhu wa tawakkal 'alayh) reinforced spiritual resilience – reminding believers that while oppressors might appear victorious, true power lies with Allah. The phrase tawakkal (reliance) here isn't passive resignation but active trust while striving ethically, knowing ultimate results rest with God.

For modern Muslims navigating global crises or personal trials, this verse offers timeless guidance. When injustice confounds us or life's unpredictability overwhelms, recognizing Allah's control of ghayb helps replace anxiety with perspective. The concluding warning that "your Lord isn't unaware" safeguards against both despair ("Allah doesn't see my pain") and complacency ("Allah won't hold me accountable"). Practically, this inspires confidence in prayer's power since the Unseen Controller hears every dua, and vigilance in actions since nothing escapes divine wisdom. By internalizing these truths – through regular worship, ethical consistency, and surrendering outcomes to Allah – believers cultivate the balance between striving and trusting that defines tawakkul.
123.layer2:
In interpreting Surah Hud 123, classical Shia exegetes emphasize the ontological and epistemological sovereignty of Allah (swt) over all creation, anchoring this verse within the framework of *tawhid* (divine unity) and the inseparable link between worship (*ibadah*) and reliance (*tawakkul*). Allama Tabatabai in *Al-Mizan* underscores that "the unseen of the heavens and earth" (*ghayb al-samawat wa al-ard*) encompasses not only hidden realities beyond human perception but also the ultimate purposes (*maqasid*) and outcomes of all created phenomena, which are solely known to Allah. This exclusive dominion, he argues, necessitates that all affairs—whether cosmic or individual—return to Him (*ilayhi yurja‘u al-amr kulluhu*), reinforcing the principle of *walayah* (divine guardianship) central to Shia theology. 

Tabrisi, in *Majma al-Bayan*, connects the imperative "worship Him and rely upon Him" to the ethical responsibility of believers, noting that true worship arises from recognizing Allah’s comprehensive knowledge and justice. The verse’s closing declaration—"your Lord is not unaware of what you do"—is interpreted as both a warning against moral complacency and an affirmation of divine *‘adl* (justice), a cornerstone of Shia doctrine. Scholars highlight that Allah’s awareness transcends mere observation; it implies a meticulous accounting tied to the eschatological framework of *ma‘ad* (resurrection), wherein every action is weighed in light of eternal truths.

Theological nuances specific to Shia thought emerge in linking this verse to the concept of *imamah*. Classical commentators implicitly correlate Allah’s guardianship over the unseen with the divinely bestowed knowledge (*‘ilm*) of the Ahl al-Bayt, who serve as custodians of spiritual and temporal guidance. While the verse explicitly addresses Allah’s omnipotence, Shia tradition extrapolates that human submission to this reality necessitates adherence to the Imam’s authority as an extension of divine command (*amr Allah*). Jurisprudentially, the call to worship and trust in Allah underpins Shia legal philosophy, where acts of devotion (*‘ibadat*) and societal transactions (*mu‘amalat*) alike derive legitimacy from their alignment with divine will. Thus, the verse synthesizes theology and praxis, reminding believers that existential reliance on Allah transcends passivity, demanding active engagement with His ordained path.
123.layer3:
In Surah Hud 11:123, the Quran distills profound truths about divine sovereignty, human agency, and cosmic mystery. Contemporary Shia scholars like Ayatollah Nasir Makarim Shirazi frame this verse as a call to harmonize trust in God (tawakkul) with proactive engagement in worldly affairs. The "unseen" (ghayb) of the heavens and earth, he notes, encompasses both metaphysical realities and undiscovered dimensions of the natural world—a concept resonating with modern physics’ exploration of dark matter or quantum fields. Scholar Dr. Mohammad Ali Shomali highlights how this verse bridges transcendence and immanence: while all existence depends on Allah’s hidden order, humans are tasked with ethical stewardship of visible creation.  

Scientifically, the "unseen" invites reflection on humanity’s limited perception. Just as dark energy shapes the cosmos undetected, systemic injustices—like algorithmic bias or climate apathy—often operate invisibly, demanding moral vigilance. Philosophically, the verse counters modern existential anxiety: ultimate control lies with the Divine, freeing us from paralyzing fear while demanding accountability. Socially, this speaks to crises like environmental collapse, urging communities to act *as if* outcomes depend on them, while trusting divine justice beyond their efforts.  

The interfaith potential here is striking. Jewish and Christian mysticism similarly emphasize divine hiddenness (hester panim in Kabbalah, "God’s depth" in Tillich’s theology). In multicultural societies, recognizing a shared "unseen" moral fabric could foster solidarity against issues like AI ethics or refugee rights. The verse’s closing reminder—"your Lord is not unaware"—challenges both complacency and despair in our hyperconnected yet fragmented world. Whether addressing tech-driven alienation or economic inequity, it calls for humility: our actions ripple through seen and unseen realms, witnessed by a Justice beyond human systems. As poetically framed by contemporary Iranian thinker Mohsen Kadivar, this verse is a compass for "active surrender"—working tirelessly for justice while anchoring hope in divine wisdom.
123.layer4:
The verse from Surah Hud draws the believer’s heart to the foundational truths of *Tawhid* (Divine Oneness) and the absolute sovereignty of Allah over all creation. The Ahlul Bayt (عليهم السلام) taught that recognizing Allah’s authority over the “unseen” and the “seen” is inseparable from recognizing His chosen guides, the Imams, who are the gateways to His mercy and the inheritors of prophetic knowledge. Imam Ali (ع) said, *“Allah is manifest through His creation, yet He is distinct from it. Nothing is hidden from Him, even the weight of an atom in the heavens or the earth”* (Nahj al-Balagha). This underscores that the “unseen” (*ghayb*) encompasses not only cosmic realities but also the spiritual truths carried by the Imams, whose wisdom illuminates the path to Allah.  

The command to *“worship Him and rely upon Him”* is deeply tied to the concept of *Wilayah* (divine guardianship). The Prophet Muhammad (ص) stated, *“I am leaving among you two weighty things: the Book of Allah and my Ahlul Bayt. If you hold fast to them, you will never go astray”* (Hadith al-Thaqalayn). Worship devoid of love and allegiance to the Ahlul Bayt lacks true substance, for they are the embodied *Tawhid* in action. Imam Jafar al-Sadiq (ع) taught, *“The cornerstone of worship is recognition (*ma’rifah*) of the Imam of your time”* (Bihar al-Anwar). Reliance (*tawakkul*) thus means entrusting one’s affairs to Allah *through* submission to His chosen guides, who manifest His will on Earth.  

The verse concludes by affirming Allah’s all-encompassing awareness: *“Your Lord is not unaware of that which you do.”* Lady Fatimah (ع) reflected this truth in her famous sermon: *“He placed upon you the trust of His guidance… so that He may test your obedience and measure your gratitude”* (Bihar al-Anwar). Every deed is observed, and every intention weighed—a truth that calls believers to align their actions with the spiritual standards set by the Ahlul Bayt. Imam Zain al-Abideen (ع) writes in the *Sahifa Sajjadiya*, *“O Allah, make me fear You as if I see You, and grant me happiness through piety in all I do.”*  

1. **Recognize the Imam’s Role:** Seek the spiritual and ethical teachings of the living Imam (Imam Mahdi, may Allah hasten his reappearance) as a means to comprehend the “unseen” truths of faith.  
2. **Worship with Sincerity:** Let every act of prayer, charity, or remembrance be infused with loyalty to the Ahlul Bayt, transforming ritual into a bridge to divine proximity.  
3. **Cultivate Trust:** Surrender anxieties to Allah by internalizing that His plan, mediated through the Imams’ guidance, is perfect.  
4. **Accountability:** Regularly self-reflect, asking: *“Would this action earn the approval of my Imam?”*  

In the light of the Ahlul Bayt, this verse becomes a roadmap to *Tawhid* in thought, worship, and ethical conduct—a journey sustained by their intercession and wisdom.

123.layer5:
Both Shia and Sunni exegetes universally affirm the core theological principles in this verse: Allah’s absolute sovereignty over creation’s unseen realms (*ghayb*), the ultimate return of all affairs to Him, and the imperative of worship (*ibadah*) coupled with trust (*tawakkul*). Al-Tabari (Sunni) and Al-Tusi (Shia) concur that the verse underscores *tawhid* (divine oneness), emphasizing Allah’s omniscience and the futility of human concealment from His knowledge, as noted in *Jami al-Bayan* and *Al-Tibyan*. Similarly, Al-Qurtubi and Al-Tabrisi highlight the ethical dimension: human accountability before an ever-aware Creator, reinforcing shared eschatological themes.  

Divergences emerge in theological extrapolation. Shia commentaries like Al-Mizan (Tabatabai) and Majma al-Bayan (Al-Tabrisi) often contextualize the “return of all matters” (*ilayhi yurja‘u al-amr*) within the framework of Imamah, interpreting it as an allusion to divine authority manifest through the Ahl al-Bayt’s guidance. Al-Qummi’s tafsir explicitly links this to the necessity of seeking spiritual and temporal refuge (*tawassul*) in the Imams as custodians of *ghayb* knowledge. Conversely, Sunni scholars like Ibn Kathir and Al-Razi (Mafatih al-Ghayb) avoid such hierarchical interpretations, focusing instead on Allah’s direct management of creation and the Sunni principle of *qadar* (divine decree), wherein human reliance (*tawakkul*) operates within predestined boundaries.  

Historically, these differences reflect distinct epistemological priorities: Shia exegesis integrates Imamah into cosmic ontology, while Sunni tradition prioritizes Allah’s transcendence and the Prophet’s Sunnah as sufficient guidance. Practically, Shia interpretations may amplify devotional practices tied to the Imams, whereas Sunni emphasis on Allah’s unmediated awareness reinforces individual accountability in worship. Both traditions, however, unite in deriving spiritual humility and ethical vigilance from this verse, demonstrating how shared Quranic principles adapt to distinct theological paradigms without doctrinal contradiction.

شیعہ اور سنی دونوں عالمی سطح پر اس آیت میں بنیادی مذہبی اصولوں کی تصدیق کرتے ہیں: اللہ کی تخلیق کے نظر نہ آنے والے دائروں (*غیب*) پر اللہ کی مطلق خودمختاری ، اس کے تمام معاملات کی حتمی واپسی ، اور اعتماد کے ساتھ مل کر عبادت (*اباداہ*) کے ساتھ مل کر۔ التباری (سنی) اور التوسی (شیعہ) نے اتفاق کیا ہے کہ آیت *تاوحد *(الہی وحدانیت) پر زور دیتی ہے ، اور اس کے علم سے اللہ کی طرف سے انسانی چھپنے کی فضولیت پر زور دیتا ہے ، جیسا کہ *جامی البیان *اور *ال تبیان *میں لکھا گیا ہے۔ اسی طرح ، القوروبی اور الاتبریسی اخلاقی جہت کو اجاگر کرتے ہیں: مشترکہ اسکیٹولوجیکل تھیمز کو تقویت بخشنے والے ، ہمیشہ سے واقف تخلیق کار سے پہلے انسانی احتساب۔  

مذہبی ایکسٹراپولیشن میں انحرافات ابھرتے ہیں۔ شیعہ تبصرے جیسے ال میزان (تبتابائی) اور مجرو البیان (الاتریسی) اکثر امامہ کے فریم ورک کے اندر "تمام معاملات کی واپسی" (*الہیہی یورجاؤ الامر*) کو سیاق و سباق سے دوچار کرتے ہیں ، اور اس کی ترجمانی اہل الل بیت کے ذریعہ الہی اتھارٹی کے حامل اختیار کے طور پر کرتے ہیں۔ القومی کا طافس اس کو واضح طور پر اماموں میں روحانی اور دنیاوی پناہ (*تواسول*) کے حصول کی ضرورت سے جوڑتا ہے جو*غیب*علم کے متولیوں کی حیثیت سے ہے۔ اس کے برعکس ، ابن کتھیر اور الراجی (مافاتیہ الغیب) جیسے سنی اسکالرز اس طرح کی درجہ بندی کی تشریحات سے گریز کرتے ہیں ، اور اس کے بجائے اللہ کی تخلیق کے براہ راست انتظام اور*قادر*(الہی فرمان) کے سنی اصول پر توجہ مرکوز کرتے ہیں ، جس میں انسانی انحصار (*طاکول*) پیش گوئی کی حدود میں کام کرتا ہے۔  

تاریخی طور پر ، یہ اختلافات الگ الگ علمی ترجیحات کی عکاسی کرتے ہیں: شیعہ استثنیٰ امامہ کو کائناتی آنٹولوجی میں ضم کرتا ہے ، جبکہ سنی روایت اللہ کی حد سے تجاوز کو ترجیح دیتی ہے اور نبی کی سنت کو کافی رہنمائی قرار دیتے ہیں۔ عملی طور پر ، شیعہ تشریحات اماموں سے منسلک عقیدت مند طریقوں کو بڑھا سکتی ہیں ، جبکہ سنی پر زور دینے سے اللہ کی غیر منقسم آگاہی عبادت میں انفرادی احتساب کو تقویت دیتی ہے۔ تاہم ، دونوں روایات اس آیت سے روحانی عاجزی اور اخلاقی چوکسی اخذ کرنے میں متحد ہوجاتی ہیں ، اور یہ ظاہر کرتی ہیں کہ مشترکہ قرآنی اصول کس طرح نظریاتی تضاد کے بغیر الگ الگ مذہبی نمونوں کے مطابق ہیں۔
